subject: Re: [junit] how to test private method with Junit?
msgSnippet: G day, I would suggest that you take a simple approach. While you are at unit test stage with incomplete code, just make the method public/protected. Once
messageBody:
G'day,

I would suggest that you take a simple approach.

While you are at unit test stage with incomplete code, just make the
method public/protected. Once you've tested it, then you can refactor it
back to private, once the public interface is completed. This should
result in most of the test being subsumed into a public interface test
or 2.

On the basis, that some other public interface (that might not be
written yet) will properly exercise it with its Unit Tests when written.
(Otherwise the code shouldn't exist).

In other words, the public interfaces to your code should be able to
fully exercise your private methods, once complete. Therefore all you
are requiring is a stop gap measure, while your code is at the current
state.


Best Rgds, Peter H.

On Thu, 2004-12-16 at 04:19, Chris Collins wrote:
> Use reflection. The example below uses the java reflection api to
> invoke a private method in the TestMe class.
>
> More information can be found at:
> http://www.onjava.com/pub/a/onjava/2003/11/12/reflection.html
>
> File: TestMe.java
> -------------------------
> public class TestMe {
> private int add(int a, int b){
> return a+b;
> }
> }
>
> File: UnitTest_TestMe.java
> ---------------------------------------
> import junit.framework.TestCase;
> import java.lang.reflect.*;
>
> public class UnitTest_TestMe extends TestCase {
> public void test_add(){
> try {
> TestMe classUnderTest = new TestMe();
> Class cls = Class.forName("TestMe");
> Class paramTypes[] = new Class[2];
> paramTypes[0] = Integer.TYPE;
> paramTypes[1] = Integer.TYPE;
> Method[] methods = cls.getDeclaredMethods();
>
> for(int i=0; i<methods.length; i++){
> if(methods[i].getName().equals("add")){
> methods[i].setAccessible(true);
> Object arglist[] = new Object[2];
> arglist[0] = new Integer(37);
> arglist[1] = new Integer(47);
> Object retobj = methods[i].invoke(classUnderTest,
> arglist);
> Integer retval = (Integer)retobj;
> assertEquals(retval.intValue(), 37+47);
> }
> }
> }
> catch (Throwable e) {
> System.err.println(e);
> fail();
> }
> }
> }
>
> Hope this helps
>
> -Chris
